subject: RE: [junit] Re: How does Unit test in a heirarchy works...
msgSnippet: ... Mhh, my definition of OO behaviour doesn t conflict at all with how Junit works. In fact from time to time I use the OO behaviour Junit shows, by
messageBody:
> Expecting OO behavior in test classes is a requirement which
> I see for my design at least.

Mhh, my definition of "OO behaviour" doesn't conflict at all with how Junit
works. In fact from time to time I use the "OO behaviour" Junit shows, by
implementing the Abstract Testcase pattern.

> I did not want to 'derail' the
> discussion from testing to making design changes and thatz
> why I made it clear that 'letz not question the design'.

Yes, I understand that.

But, as I tried to say earlier, the "inventors" of Junit, and many of their
users, actually actively *use* writing tests as a design technique. So
"questioning the design" actually doesn't sound like "derailing" to me, but
quite on topic. Your mileage may vary, of course.

> Also someone was of the opinion that deep heirarchy could be
> a bad design..I wanted to step-in and say 'of course not..it has it's
> own reason'.

I believe you that you have your reasons. What I'm not going to believe that
easily is that the design really cannot possibly be improved by flattening
the hierarchy - that simply too strongly contradicts my experience. It would
have been interesting to discuss this specific instance, and I would have
expected to learn something from it. But I also understand and respect that
you are not interested in such a discussion.

>> > In real life, faulty or imperfect designs are the norm.
>>
>> Sure. That's one reason unit testing is so valuable: it makes some
>> of the imperfectionism more visible, so that we can work on it.

> 'Faulty or imperfect design'- well thatz not the case when we
> can't use jUnit for this purpose.

I don't understand what you want to say here.

> Sometimes the app design might
> not provide interfaces to such a granular level that unit
> test might need. It doesn't mean the design is imperfect or
> sub-optimal.

With all due respect, in my experience it very likely means exactly that, as
it means that things are rather strongly coupled. But perhaps we should
simply agree to disagree here...?

No hard feelings,

Ilja
